span.p: All buildings closed for the remainder of the 2019-2020 school year, as directed by Governor DeWine. Check back for updates.

a.span: Logo link to home page, panther in red and white circle

strong.span: Click below to fill out the form:

p.strong: Q: What are plans for Prom, graduation and Senior Awards night?

span.p: A: We believe that graduation and Prom are a rite of passage for seniors so our intent is to have something for both. In all likelihood they will be delayed, perhaps even late summer, as we need to hear from the Governor as to what will be permissible for schools and a large group activity. Once we get information it will be addressed. Our Superintendent, High School Administrators and our Board have been discussing this, so be assured the issue will be addressed as soon as possible.

For Senior Awards night, we will be working on a virtual presentation to recognize those students who have won a scholarship or other recognition. It will be released to the public and made widely available.

p.strong: Q: If school is closed for the rest of the school year, how do seniors return/ get their stuff from lockers? including Chromebooks and books?

span.p: A: Obviously this is an issue for all schools and we have been discussing it internally as well as with other districts. We are formulating plans to bring in small groups assigned to come in during specific times. We hope to have these formalized by the week of April 27th. As soon as we have more direction, we will release plans.

p.strong: Q: Are you still doing kindergarten screenings May 6th?

span.p: Kindergarten registration and screening that was scheduled for May 6th has been postponed. We plan to hopefully reschedule over the summer. The district is currently looking into the possibility of online registration. As soon as we have a new date for screening and registration we will post it on panthercountry.org.

p.strong: Q: What is going to happen with the 8th grade trip to Washington DC?

span.p: A: The trip is cancelled and the school is working with the company to negotiate refunds. Although the deposit put down was termed "non-refundable" on the application, we are hopeful to get some of that money returned to our families.

p.strong: Q: What is happening with the AP Exams for students in the AP classes?

br.br: A: All of our AP staff and all have reached out to our students and the students are aware of the ability to take the AP Exam at home. If any student has a question regarding their particular exam they should contact their teacher.

span.p: Our AP teachers are staying up to date on everything that is coming out from the College Board and working hard to continue to prepare our AP students. We have opened up the secure browser app that students will need to download on their Chromebook.
From CollegeBoard AP:

p.span: AP Updates for Schools Impacted by Coronavirus

span.p: As schools and communities navigate the unprecedented challenges posed by the coronavirus (COVID-19) outbreak, the health and safety of educators and students are the AP® Program’s top priorities. Through our members across the country, we understand the new time constraints on everyone in the education community. These solutions are meant to be as simple and lightweight as possible for both students and teachers—without creating additional burdens for school leaders during this time.
AP Exam Administration
• Traditional face-to-face exam administrations will not take place. Students will take a 45-minute online free-response exam at home.

• Some students may want to take the exam sooner rather than later, while the content is still fresh. Other students may want more time to practice. For each AP subject, there will be two different testing dates.
• The full exam schedule, specific free-response question types that will be on each AP Exam, and additional testing details will be available by April 3, 2020.
Instructional Support
• Beginning on Wednesday, March 25, students and teachers can attend free, live AP review courses, delivered by AP teachers from across the country.
• These mobile-friendly classes, designed to be used alongside work that may be given by schools, will also be available on demand, so teachers and students can access them at any time.
• Teachers who are providing remote instruction can continue to leverage AP Classroom, which we introduced at the start of the school year.

• Within AP Classroom, free-response questions that were only available for inclassroom use due to security concerns will now be unlocked. Teachers will be able to assign questions to students digitally.
Please visit AP Central (https://apcentral.collegeboard.org/about-ap/newschanges/coronavirus-update), which will be updated as we have additional information and resources.

p.strong: Q: My child has materials in their locker (or locker room, etc.), would there be any way we could get those?

span.p: A: Unfortunately, we cannot allow students in the building at this time. However, we can arrange to get items placed in a bag for pickup and place them outside the building at an arranged time if it absolutely necessary. We have done this at the high school for Chromebooks and materials needed for AP testing. If you have a need that is an absolute must, (including medication), please contact your building Principal. For all other students in all 3 buildings, administration is working on a formalized plan to get students in a few at a time at a later date to retrieve items and hand in materials.

p.strong: Q: What is happening with Varsity Athletic Letters earned in Winter Sports?

br.br: A: Winter sport athletes who were on course to receive an athletic letter will be awarded those once we return to school, hopefully later this spring. If we are not able to return to school by order of the State Director of Health and you are a senior or underclassman the Athletic Department will award those letters once allowed to return; even if in the fall. Be assured all athletes will be recognized and awarded once we can return to school.
